column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=A variety of methods have been proposed to create relatively short fractures to decrease near wellbore resistance to flow.
#Text=Of course, the obvious method is to perform a conventional hydraulic fracturing treatment but pump less quantities of fluid and proppant.
#Text=This method is widely practiced, often under the name "minifrac."
#Text=Unfortunately, the cost of assembling the equipment for such small jobs limits the usefulness of the minifrac.
#Text=Other processes have been proposed.
#Text=U.S.
#Text=Pat.

#Text=No. 4,633,951 discloses use of combustion gas generating units and a cased wellbore filled with compressible hydraulic fracturing fluid, such as foam, the fracturing fluid containing proppant particles.
#Text=The pressure of the compressible fluid is increased to a pressure in excess of the fracturing pressure of the formation--sometimes far in excess.
#Text=The casing of the wellbore is then perforated to release the compressible fluid and particles through the perforations at high pressures.
#Text=The fractures formed are sanded off until the perforations become plugged with proppant particles.
#Text=U.S.
#Text=Pat.

#Text=No. 4,718,493, a continuation-in-part of the '951 patent, discloses continued injection of the compressible fracturing fluid after perforating the casing until fluid leak-off causes proppant to plug the fracture back to the wellbore.
#Text=Proppant at moderate to high concentrations in the fracturing fluid is proposed.
#Text=U.S.
#Text=Pat.

#Text=No. 3,170,517 discloses a method of creating a relatively small hydraulic fracture from a wellbore by placing a fracturing fluid, which may be an acid or may contain proppant, in a well, building up gas pressure above the fracturing fluid, and perforating the casing of the well.
#Text=Fracturing pressure of the formation is applied from the gas only until the gas pressure is depleted by flow from the wellbore.
#Text=Most wells for hydrocarbon production contain steel casing which traverses the formation to be produced.
#Text=The well is completed by perforating this casing.
#Text=Three types of perforating equipment are commonly used: (1) shaped charge, (2) bullet, and (3) high-pressure jets of fluid.
#Text=The shaped-charge gun is by far the most common.

#Text=The perforation formed must penetrate the steel casing and preferably will penetrate the zone of damaged permeability which often extends for a few inches around a wellbore as a result of processes occurring during drilling of the hole.
#Text=The most common method of placing perforating apparatus in a well is attaching it to an electrically conducting cable, called an "electric wire line."
#Text=This type perforating gun can be run through tubing in a well to perforate casing below the tubing; larger diameter guns can be run in casing only.
#Text=In recent times, a method of perforating called "tubing-conveyed perforating" has been developed.

#Text=In this method, apparatus is attached to the bottom of the tubing before it is run into a well and the firing of the charges is initiated by dropping of a bar down through the tubing or by a pressure-activated firing device.
#Text=Vent valves, automatic dropping of the gun from the bottom of the tubing after firing and other features can be used along with tubing-conveyed perforating.
#Text=The use of high pressure gas in a wellbore to clean perforations has been described.
#Text=In the paper "The Multiwell Experiment--A Field Laboratory in Tight Gas Sandstone Reservoirs," J.
#Text=Pet.
#Text=Tech.

#Text=June, 1990, p. 775, the authors describe perforating a zone while the casing was pressurized with nitrogen gas to around 3,000 psi above the formation fracturing stress to achieve excellent communication with the formation, believed to be the result of cleaning the perforations with the high pressure nitrogen and preventing contact of the formation by liquids.
#Text=Also, the paper "Hydraulic Fracturing in Tight, Fissured Media," J.
#Text=Pet.
#Text=Tech., Feb.,1991, p. 151, describes procedures for perforating in high-pressure nitrogen gas.

#Text=To increase the effectiveness of fracturing or any other stimulation method, it is important to treat all existing the perforations A variety of "diversion" techniques are used in an effort to insure that fracturing fluid or other stimulation fluid enters all open perforations.

#Text=Such methods as pumping "ball sealers," pumping gel diverting slugs and pumping oil-soluble resin particles, sized salt, benzoic acid flakes and other sized particles into perforations are commonly used.
#Text=But all these methods are very limited in their capabilities to divert fluids to every existing perforation.
